Empires & Puzzles Roz Review: The Natural Sharpshooter Guide

Roz brings a unique mechanic to the battlefield: the more Nature shields you have, the harder she hits. Is this Super Elemental sniper worth the gamble of a bad board, or is she just a conditional hitter in a world of reliable nukes? We dive deep into her stats and skills.
Roz: The Green Archer Who Needs a Full Quiver (of Tiles)
Roz: When "Going Green" Means Total Destruction (Ideally)

Roz is a 5-star Legendary Nature hero from the Super Elemental family, originally released back in late 2022. She fits the archetype of a fast sniper who dreams of being an Area of Effect (AoE) monster. Her gimmick is entirely reliant on the number of Nature shields on the board when she fires. In a game that often rewards consistency, Roz asks you to gamble on the board state. This review focuses on her
, a Ranger who loves her troops almost as much as she loves green tiles.

Roz sports a futuristic, cyber-archer aesthetic with glowing green neon accents. It is a very distinct look that screams "tech-savvy elf" rather than your traditional fantasy ranger. The glowing bow and the determined wink give her a confident vibe, like she knows exactly where that arrow is going... provided you have enough green tiles to make it count. Compared to her Disco-themed costume, this base version is much more combat-pragmatic and less about the party life.

Looking at her stats, base Roz shows her age. With a power level of 970, she sits significantly behind modern heroes who are pushing 1200+ raw power (her own costume hits 1221). Her attack stat of 939 is respectable for her era but average by today's standards. Her defense (908) and health (1874) leave her somewhat squishy compared to the tanky behemoths released in recent months. She relies heavily on emblems and limit breaks to survive against modern hitters.
is a fascinating, if frustrating, skill. At its core, it is a fast 530% snipe. That is solid. However, the "kicker" mechanics are where the debate begins:
She hits the target and nearby enemies.

The problem is the requirement. Getting 12 tiles of your color on the board while also having your special ready usually means you are already winning or you have been holding her charge for too long. The 6-tile threshold is more manageable, turning her into a hit-3 hero, but even that is not guaranteed.
Fast. She charges in 8 tiles (7 with mana troops/bonuses). This speed is her saving grace, allowing her to fire often, even if the board is not fully primed for her secondary effects.
530% is a heavy hit. Against a target with roughly equal defense, this is a kill shot on weakened enemies.
If you trigger the hit-all (12 tiles), 530% to all at Fast speed is nuclear. However, the probability of this happening in a competitive match is low (estimated <5% of fires).
Her Troop Mastery passive is huge. +100% elemental damage from troops against weaker elements (Blue) means her tile damage against Blue tanks is absolutely devastating.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Super Elemental family is all about tile manipulation and elemental dominance.
bonus modifies shields of the hero's element. It makes your green tiles deal more damage or generate more mana, which is nice, but the real meat is in the passive.
is the defining feature of this family.

+100% extra elemental damage against weaker elements. If you bring Roz against a Blue tank, your green tiles hit like trucks. This often makes her valuable for the tile damage alone, regardless of her special skill.
-10% received elemental damage from the stronger element (Red). This helps her survivability slightly against red stacks.
is a functional, if unexciting, Aether Power. It helps mitigate her aging defense stat, keeping her alive long enough to maybe find those elusive 12 tiles.
Upon release, Roz was seen as a high-potential hero. Players loved the idea of a fast hit-all nuke, even if conditional. She was a titan specialist thanks to her tile damage passive.

Today, a 530% sniper is "okay," but not game-breaking. Modern heroes like Jove or even newer snipers do more reliable damage or offer game-changing utility (silence, mana control) without needing board conditions.

Base Roz is now a niche hero. She is viable in wars against Blue tanks specifically for the tile damage boost. In general PvP, she is too inconsistent compared to modern options. She has largely been replaced by her own Costume or newer, more reliable nature hitters.
The arrival of her costume (the "Disco Sharpshooter") was a massive upgrade that essentially saved the hero from obsolescence.
The costume brings her power from 970 to 1221. This is a massive leap that makes her tanky enough for modern wars.
The costume changes the damage slightly (540%) but crucially lowers the tile requirements:
6 tiles for hit-3, 12 tiles for hit-all.
5 tiles for hit-3, 10 tiles for hit-all.
Base is Ranger (Pierce); Costume is Rogue (Dodge). While Pierce is great for offense, Dodge is superior for survival.

The Costume is strictly better in almost every scenario due to the stats and easier conditions. However, the Base form's Ranger class can still be useful if you desperately need to bypass defensive buffs (like counterattack).
As a Ranger, Roz benefits from the ability to bypass defensive buffs.
Maximizes her 530% snipe and her already high tile damage against Blue enemies.
She remains fragile and might die before firing.
Keeps her alive longer, increasing the chance you can manipulate the board to get 6+ tiles.
Reduces the impact of her sniper shot and her primary asset: tile damage.

is recommended. Roz's main job is to kill things quickly. Her passive multiplies damage based on her troops and attack stat, so lean into her strength. If she dies, she dies, but if she connects, she should secure a kill.
The passive +100% damage vs Blue is incredible for stacking.
In the rare event you get 12 tiles, she wipes the board.
Bypassing defensive buffs is always relevant.
Most of the time, she is just a single-target sniper.
charging is counter-intuitive (you usually match tiles to charge her, consuming them).
Without the costume bonus or limit breaks, she is squishy.
Her passive makes her a top-tier choice for Blue Titans.
specifically against Blue tanks or heavy Blue teams.
Fast speed + high damage is always good here.
The key to using Roz is bringing friends who manipulate the board or do not consume green tiles to charge.
. Elemental Defense Down (Evelyn/Almur) ensures that when Roz hits, she kills.
. Ratatoskr generates green tiles, helping Roz hit her 6 or 12 tile condition while Tarlak boosts the damage.
Heroes who reduce accuracy or blind (Drake Fong, Justice) can ruin her one big shot. Mana controllers who stop her from firing while you set up the board.
Other fast green heroes who need tiles to fire. You might find yourself "stealing" tiles from Roz's board requirement just to charge a teammate.

If you pulled Roz early, she is a fantastic sniper. Focus on her attack. Don't stress too much about the 12-tile condition; treat it as a lucky bonus. Treat her as a fast sniper who kills one enemy reliably.

Base Roz is likely a benchwarmer unless you are fighting a Blue Titan. If you have the costume, level it immediately. If not, she is a depth hero for War teams. Do not prioritize Alpha Aethers on the base version alone unless you have no modern green hitters.
The community has always been torn on Roz.
"At 0.1% odds, this is just a sniper with 500% attack. Sure, it can be a hit 3 hero, but you have to get more greens to appear... a far cry from Jove."
Another lamented the difficulty of the mechanic:
"To my surprise, it’s not that hard to get 6 green... It’s just the 12th that will be rare & elusive."
However, the tile damage has its fans:
"All elemental heroes are pretty nasty due to their passive... The damage from those gems accumulates quickly."

Roz is a hero with an identity crisis. She wants to be an AoE destroyer, but physics (and board RNG) usually force her to be a sniper. While her base stats are gathering dust, her passive ability ensures she hits like a truck against Blue enemies. If you have her costume, she is a star. If you only have the base version, she is a specialized tool for killing titans and cracking blue tanks, but she is no longer the queen of the jungle.
A conditional powerhouse who is great when the stars align, but average when they don't.
